class ConvLayer[source]

Construct a Sequence of Conv -> BN -> Act

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_forward(ConvLayer(3,3)) # with stride 1 input size should be equal output size
test_forward(ConvLayer(3,3,transpose=True))
test_forward(ConvLayer(3,3,stride=2), check_size=False)
test_forward(ConvLayer(3,3,transpose=True, stride=2), check_size=False)

class ResBlock[source]

ResBlock like implementation for 3D

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_forward(ResBlock(3,64, bottleneck = False))
test_forward(ResBlock(3,64, bottleneck = True))
test_forward(ResBlock(3,3, bottleneck = False))
test_forward(ResBlock(3,3, bottleneck = True, groups = 2))

class DoubleConv[source]

DoubleConv(in_c, ks=3, stride=1, padding='auto', pad_value=0.0, norm=BatchNorm3d, act=ReLU, transpose=False, dilation:Union[int, Tuple[int, int, int]]=1, groups:int=1, bias:bool=True, padding_mode:str='zeros') :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

:ivar training: Boolean represents whether this module is in training or evaluation mode. :vartype training: bool

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_forward(DoubleConv(3))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class DeepSupervision[source]

DeepSupervision(in_c, out_c, ks=1, act=None, norm=None, stride=1, padding='auto', pad_value=0.0, transpose=False, dilation:Union[int, Tuple[int, int, int]]=1, groups:int=1, bias:bool=True, padding_mode:str='zeros') :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

:ivar training: Boolean represents whether this module is in training or evaluation mode. :vartype training: bool

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
test_forward(DeepSupervision(3,3))
test_forward(DeepSupervision(3,2))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
